pos_items.definition: used to give information about someone or something
dictionary_examples: I'm tired.
I'm very well, thank you.
Hi, I'm Sylvie.
He's tall.
They aren't German, they're from Austria.
He was six at the time.
They were late.
The film was great.
Her house isn't very big.
learner_examples: My friend's name is Sarah. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone or something exists
dictionary_examples: There are six Italians in the class.
There are three bedrooms.
There's a shop at the end of the road.
There was a good programme on TV last night.
Is there a problem?
learner_examples: There are many interesting things. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to say or ask where someone or something is
dictionary_examples: He's in the garden.
Are you there?
I'm here!
The plates are in this cupboard.
Where is that letter?
learner_examples: My college is in Braintree. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone has gone to a place and returned from that place
dictionary_examples: I've been to Mexico.
Have you ever been to the US?
learner_examples: I like Japanese people and I've been to Japan three times. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used with the present participle of other verbs to describe actions that are or were still continuing
dictionary_examples: I'm still eating.
She's studying to be a lawyer.
The audience clearly wasn't enjoying the show.
You're always complaining.
I'll be coming back on Tuesday.
learner_examples: I'm thinking of painting it blue. (Key English Test; A2; Albanian)

pos_items.definition: used with the past participle of other verbs to form the passive
dictionary_examples: This dessert is made from eggs, sugar, and cream.
A body was discovered by the police.
The results will be announced next week.
I haven't been invited.
They were asked to leave.
learner_examples: I like it very much, because it is interesting and it was written by an excellent author, Lev Tolstoy. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used to give information about someone or something
dictionary_examples: I'm tired.
I'm very well, thank you.
Hi, I'm Sylvie.
He's tall.
They aren't German, they're from Austria.
He was six at the time.
They were late.
The film was great.
Her house isn't very big.
learner_examples: My friend's name is Sarah. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone or something exists
dictionary_examples: There are six Italians in the class.
There are three bedrooms.
There's a shop at the end of the road.
There was a good programme on TV last night.
Is there a problem?
learner_examples: There are many interesting things. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to say or ask where someone or something is
dictionary_examples: He's in the garden.
Are you there?
I'm here!
The plates are in this cupboard.
Where is that letter?
learner_examples: My college is in Braintree. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone has gone to a place and returned from that place
dictionary_examples: I've been to Mexico.
Have you ever been to the US?
learner_examples: I like Japanese people and I've been to Japan three times. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: used with the present participle of other verbs to describe actions that are or were still continuing
dictionary_examples: I'm still eating.
She's studying to be a lawyer.
The audience clearly wasn't enjoying the show.
You're always complaining.
I'll be coming back on Tuesday.
learner_examples: I'm thinking of painting it blue. (Key English Test; A2; Albanian)

pos_items.definition: used with the past participle of other verbs to form the passive
dictionary_examples: This dessert is made from eggs, sugar, and cream.
A body was discovered by the police.
The results will be announced next week.
I haven't been invited.
They were asked to leave.
learner_examples: I like it very much, because it is interesting and it was written by an excellent author, Lev Tolstoy. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: used with another verb to form questions and negative phrases
dictionary_examples: Do you speak English?
Where do you work?
When does your train leave?
Why did you say that?
I don't know.
He doesn't eat meat.
I didn't see her there.
learner_examples: What did you do at [the] party? (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.sense_title: don't you?/do you?/doesn't she?/does she?, etc.
pos_items.definition: used in a phrase at the end of a sentence to make the sentence a question
dictionary_examples: You like her, don't you?
Sarah lives near here, doesn't she?
You didn't ask him, did you?
It doesn't hurt, does it?
learner_examples: You love watch[ing] tv, don't you?! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: something you say when politely asking if you can do something, or when asking someone else to do something
dictionary_examples: Do you mind if I put the television on?
learner_examples: Do you mind if I bring a friend? (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to be unsuccessful/successful
dictionary_examples: Sam did very well in her exams.
learner_examples: I had done badly in my last exam and my teacher said she would talk to my mother. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil)

pos_items.definition: used to avoid repeating a verb that has just been used
dictionary_examples: She runs much faster than he does.
Maria looks much healthier than she did.
"I hate that song!" "So do I."
"I don't like the heat." "Nor/Neither do I."
"May I join you?" "Please do!"
learner_examples: I like Brad Pitt a lot, and so does she. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.definition: used to give extra force to the main verb
dictionary_examples: Do let me know if you need anything.
He does like you - he's just shy.
learner_examples: I real[l]y do love to be a volunteer, to help people as much as I can. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Romanian)

pos_items.definition: to perform an action
dictionary_examples: What shall we do?
What are you doing tonight?
Have you done your homework?
We did a lot of talking.
I've got nothing to do.
learner_examples: I have nothing to do. (Key English Test; A2; Chinese)

pos_items.definition: to study a subject
dictionary_examples: Diana did history at university.
learner_examples: I'm doing English [at] the college. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: to perform a job in the house
dictionary_examples: I do the cooking but Joe does most of the cleaning.
learner_examples: She like[s] to do [the] cooking. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: used to ask what someone's job is
dictionary_examples: "What do you do (for a living)?" "I'm a doctor."
What does Antonio do - does he teach?
I don't know what his wife does.
learner_examples: What does Angie do? (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: to make or produce something
dictionary_examples: I've done 20 copies of the hand-out.
They do really good cakes in the cafe.
learner_examples: [On] any sp[e]cial day [like] Devali they do some sp[e]cial sweet food. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Arabic)

pos_items.definition: used for talking or asking about someone and whether they are healthy, happy or succeeding
dictionary_examples: Hi, how are you doing?
"How is Freya doing?" "She's doing really well, thanks."
learner_examples: I'm doing fine. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Estonian)

pos_items.definition: to perform a sports activity
dictionary_examples: She does yoga in her spare time.
learner_examples: [At the club,] I can swim, do karate [or] yoga, play soccer, tennis, squash and table-tennis. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: to make your hair/make-up, etc. look nice
dictionary_examples: It takes him half an hour to do his hair in the morning.
learner_examples: I was the assistant of the person responsible for the clothes and make-up of the pop-group, [and] I was asked to do their make-up on my o[w]n. (First Certificate in English; B2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: to make the greatest effort possible
dictionary_examples: I did my best to persuade him.
learner_examples: I'll do my best to cover the work. (Preliminary English Test; B1; French)

pos_items.definition: to have a good effect on someone
dictionary_examples: A break from this would do us all good.
learner_examples: I must admit that my stay in your nice home did me good. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to cause damage/harm, etc.
dictionary_examples: The fire did a lot of structural damage to the building.
learner_examples: I promise not to do any damage! (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to be related to something
dictionary_examples: She lacks confidence and I think that has to do with her childhood.
learner_examples: I think that is nothing to do with my accident. (Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: will be satisfactory
dictionary_examples: You don't have to pay now, next week will do.
learner_examples: You need a telephone card. They can cost from 100zT to 1000zT. One of 100zT will do. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to try as hard as you can to do something
dictionary_examples: We did our utmost to finish the project on time.
learner_examples: In addition, we l[i]ve in a materialistic society where we all do our utmost in order to make ends meet, but we are never satisfied. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek)

pos_items.definition: If something does the job, it is suitable for a particular purpose.
dictionary_examples: Here, this knife should do the job.
learner_examples: Allow them to bring home friends and therefore develop social skills. In my opinion, that should do the job. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.sense_title: do sb/sth justice; do justice to sb/sth
pos_items.definition: to show the best or real qualities of something or someone
dictionary_examples: This postcard doesn't do justice to the wonderful scenery.
learner_examples: No words can do justice to the indignation that I feel. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that something is not a suitable or practical thing to do
dictionary_examples: I couldn't very well tell her while he was there.
learner_examples: I couldn't very well tell her that without my diaries, I'd be lost and not know who I was. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to accept something that is less good than you would like
dictionary_examples: If we can't get a bigger room we'll have to make do with this.
learner_examples: Very calmly, he said "I am not going to put up with this. You might say that I am being too emotional, overreacting, whatever. But I will not come back until my piano has been returned. And let me make very clear that I will not make do with another instrument." (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If something does the trick, it solves a problem or has the result you want.
dictionary_examples: If I've got a headache, a couple of aspirins usually do the trick.
learner_examples: Using aromatherapy oil and scented candles always did the trick when she wanted to relax. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used with another verb to form questions and negative phrases
dictionary_examples: Do you speak English?
Where do you work?
When does your train leave?
Why did you say that?
I don't know.
He doesn't eat meat.
I didn't see her there.
learner_examples: What did you do at [the] party? (Key English Test; A2; Italian)

pos_items.sense_title: don't you?/do you?/doesn't she?/does she?, etc.
pos_items.definition: used in a phrase at the end of a sentence to make the sentence a question
dictionary_examples: You like her, don't you?
Sarah lives near here, doesn't she?
You didn't ask him, did you?
It doesn't hurt, does it?
learner_examples: You love watch[ing] tv, don't you?! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

learner_examples: Allow them to bring home friends and therefore develop social skills. In my opinion, that should do the job. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German)

pos_items.definition: to show the best or real qualities of something or someone
dictionary_examples: This postcard doesn't do justice to the wonderful scenery.
learner_examples: No words can do justice to the indignation that I feel. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

dictionary_examples: I couldn't very well tell her while he was there.
learner_examples: I couldn't very well tell her that without my diaries, I'd be lost and not know who I was. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish)

pos_items.definition: to accept something that is less good than you would like
dictionary_examples: If we can't get a bigger room we'll have to make do with this.
learner_examples: Very calmly, he said "I am not going to put up with this. You might say that I am being too emotional, overreacting, whatever. But I will not come back until my piano has been returned. And let me make very clear that I will not make do with another instrument." (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: If something does the trick, it solves a problem or has the result you want.
dictionary_examples: If I've got a headache, a couple of aspirins usually do the trick.
learner_examples: Using aromatherapy oil and scented candles always did the trick when she wanted to relax. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French)

pos_items.definition: used with the past participle of another verb to form the present and past perfect tenses
dictionary_examples: Have you seen Roz?
I've passed my test.
He hasn't visited London yet.
I'd met his wife before.
It would have been better to tell the truth.
He's been working in France for two years now.
learner_examples: I haven't seen you for ages. (Key English Test; A2; Russian)

pos_items.definition: to need to do something or be forced to do something
dictionary_examples: I've got to go to Manchester tomorrow.
Do we have to finish this today?
They've had to change their plans.
learner_examples: Dear Mr Miller, Unfortunately I'm going to miss the English class tomorrow because I'm ill. Yest[e]rday I went to the doctor and he said that I've got to stay at home for three days. (Preliminary English Test; B1; German)

pos_items.definition: used when you are telling someone how to do something
dictionary_examples: You have to wait for the green light and then record your voice.
You've got to type in your name, then your password.
learner_examples: To get to my house, you have to get bus [number] 30 to town, [and] there you have to get bus [number] 15 to Spring Bank. (Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: used to say that you feel certain that something is true or will happen
dictionary_examples: Interest rates have to come down at some point.
There's (=there has) got to be a better way of doing this.
learner_examples: There has to be a solution to this. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to own or possess
dictionary_examples: They have a big house.
He has blue eyes.
I've got two brothers.
He's got a degree.
She has a lot of experience.
Have you got time to finish the report today?
learner_examples: I had [a] big house in Somalia, now I hav[e] [a] small house. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali)

pos_items.definition: If you have a particular illness, you suffer from it.
dictionary_examples: I've got a cold.
Have you ever had measles?
learner_examples: I know you had [the] flu. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to eat or drink something
dictionary_examples: I had prawns and rice for lunch.
Can I have a drink of water?
Let's have a coffee before the film.
When are we having dinner?
learner_examples: I have dinner [at] 5 pm. (Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French)

pos_items.definition: to give birth to a baby
dictionary_examples: Elaine had a baby girl yesterday.
learner_examples: She had got married and had had a baby without telling me! (Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian)

pos_items.sense_title: have fun/a nice time/a problem, etc.
pos_items.definition: to experience something
dictionary_examples: Have a nice day!
We had a great time in Venice.
We had a few problems finding the house.
Did you have any luck finding a present for Annie?
learner_examples: We played a lot of games and had fun. (Key English Test; A2; Singhalese)

pos_items.definition: used with nouns to say that someone does something
dictionary_examples: Can I have a quick shower?
Let's have a walk along the river.
learner_examples: If you want you can have a shower after play[ing] tennis. (Key English Test; A2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to pay someone to do something for you
dictionary_examples: I'm having my hair cut this afternoon.
I've had my watch mended.
We're having the house painted next month.
learner_examples: My mother is having her car repaired. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If you have something stolen/taken, etc. someone takes something that belongs to you.
dictionary_examples: She had her car stolen last week.
I had my bag taken.
learner_examples: He told me over the phone that he had arrived in London with his wife, but shortly after the arrival, he had ha[d] his wallet stolen in the underground station. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean)

pos_items.definition: to cause something to be in a particular state
dictionary_examples: He had dinner ready by the time we got home.
We had the tent up within ten minutes.
learner_examples: We had everything ready in case of an emergency or a chaos situation. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: used to say that someone is holding something, or that someone or something is with them
dictionary_examples: He had a pen in his hand.
She had a little boy with her.
learner_examples: Maria had the phone in her hand. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish)

pos_items.definition: to not know
dictionary_examples: "Where's Serge?" "I've no idea."
learner_examples: I have no idea about how his children are. (Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese)

pos_items.definition: If you have someone over/round, etc. you arrange for someone to visit you in your home.
dictionary_examples: We had Justyna and Al round for dinner last week.
learner_examples: I'd like to thank you once more for having me round [to] your house. (First Certificate in English; B2; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to arrange for someone to do something
dictionary_examples: If you wait, I'll have someone collect it for you.
I'll have my secretary call her this afternoon.
learner_examples: I would like to request you, as a manager, to either have someone fix the problem with the microwave or simply replace it. (International English Language Testing System; C2; Ulithian)

pos_items.definition: to be completely unable to guess, understand, or deal with something
dictionary_examples: I haven't a clue what you're talking about.
learner_examples: I haven't a clue about it. (First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese)

pos_items.definition: to talk to someone for a short time
dictionary_examples: Could I have a word (with you) about the sales figures?
Perhaps you would have a quiet word with Simon about the problem.
learner_examples: The nurse sitting beside me said to me, 'Your mother would like to have a word with you,' then she went out. (First Certificate in English; B2; Thai)

pos_items.sense_title: have nothing to do with sb/sth
pos_items.definition: to have no connection or influence with someone or something
dictionary_examples: He made his own decision - I had nothing to do with it.
learner_examples: Of course, I tried to explain [to] him that I had nothing to do with the vanishing of the cake but he didn't trust me. (First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish)

pos_items.sense_title: have nothing to do with sb
pos_items.definition: If something is or has nothing to do with you, you have no good reason to know about it or be involved with it.
dictionary_examples: I wish he wouldn't offer advice on my marriage - it's nothing to do with him.
learner_examples: The party was horrible: the guests were all talking about things that had nothing to do with me. (First Certificate in English; B2; Italian)

pos_items.definition: to have a reason not to like someone or something
dictionary_examples: I've got nothing against him personally, I just don't think he's the right man for the job.
learner_examples: If you have nothing against taking public transport, I suggest taking a bus. (Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish)

pos_items.definition: to dislike someone and want to cause problems for them
dictionary_examples: She really has it in for me - I don't know what I've done to offend her.
learner_examples: Only then did she realise that somebody had it in for her. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek)

pos_items.definition: used to emphasize that you do not know something
dictionary_examples: I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about.
learner_examples: Some twenty years ago, when I left my parents' home to go and live on my own, I was [given] four mugs. By whom? I haven't the faintest idea. (Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch)
